page.title: 06HOME LIFE IN ASKHAM
page.content: The meaning of the name {ASKHAM. { Askr}is the old Norse form of ash tree. { Ham}occurs in most Germanic languages and denotes a village or dwelling place. The Church in Askham is dedicated to St. Nicholas. The parish of Askham has 1440 acres of grass and 1140 acres of arable. They generally grow oilseed rape,sugarbeet, potatoes, beans, wheat, barley and oats. Some of the farmers own dairy cattle which are mainly Friesian. They also keep cattle for beef which are also Friesians and Herefords. The soil is clayish and the average rainfall is 22 inches a year. In 1985 there were 196 inhabitants who lived in 62 houses and a pub. There is one bus stop and a telephone box. A mobile butcher and library visit the area occasionally.
